list.text_description: Sandugong Panaguinip (Dreamed Alliance), allegedly the first Filipino full-length opera, composed by Ladislao Bonus and with libretto by Pedro Paterno (1857-1911), is premiered.

list.media_caption: Walter Howard Loving, director of the Philippine Constabulary band
list.media_credit: In Performance: Walter Loving and the Philippine Constabulary Band by Dr Robert L. Yoder. National Historical Commission of the Philippines, 2013.
list.article_title: The Philippine Constabulary (PC) Band is founded by Col Walter H. Loving (1872-1945) with an initial membership of 30 musicians, later expanding to 80 members.
list.text_description: The Philippine Constabulary (PC) Band is founded by Col Walter H. Loving (1872-1945) with an initial membership of 30 musicians, later expanding to 80 members.

list.media_caption: Trompe l’oeil paintings inside the San Agustin Church, 2014
list.media_credit: Photo by Betty Lalana and Lino Arboleda, Ortigas Foundation Library Collection
list.article_title: Pequeña Misa Solemne sobre Motivos de la Missa Regia del Canto Gregoriano by Marcelo Adonay (1848-1928) is first performed in a “high mass” at San Agustin church.
list.text_description: Pequeña Misa Solemne sobre Motivos de la Missa Regia del Canto Gregoriano by Marcelo Adonay (1848-1928) is first performed in a “high mass” at San Agustin church.

list.media_caption: Juan S. Hernandez conducting the premiere performance of his Piano Concerto in D Minor with daughter Carmencita on the piano, ca 1950
list.article_title: Severino Reyes’s orientalist zarzuela Minda Mora with music by Juan S. Hernandez (1881-1945), is premiered in Manila Grand Opera House.
list.text_description: Severino Reyes’s orientalist zarzuela Minda Mora with music by Juan S. Hernandez (1881-1945), is premiered in Manila Grand Opera House.

list.media_caption: Philippine Constabulary band at the St Louis World’s Fair, USA, 1904
list.article_title: The Philippine Constabulary (PC) Band wins second prize in the St Louis Exposition. Also in the exposition are Jose Estella’s pieces, Diego Perez’s “Recuerdos,” traditional music from indigenous groups, and local music inventions such as Pio Trinidad’s first piano of Filipino manufacture, featuring Trinidad’s tremolofon device and Jose Canseco’s “tonopsis mecanica.” All win industry awards.
list.text_description: The Philippine Constabulary (PC) Band wins second prize in the St Louis Exposition. Also in the exposition are Jose Estella’s pieces, Diego Perez’s “Recuerdos,” traditional music from indigenous groups, and local music inventions such as Pio Trinidad’s first piano of Filipino manufacture, featuring Trinidad’s tremolofon device and Jose Canseco’s “tonopsis mecanica.” All win industry awards.

list.media_caption: Sheet music cover of “¡Amor! A Song of Love” dedicated to Jovita Fuentes, then treasurer of the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas, ca 1920
list.article_title: The Asociacion Musical de Filipinas is formed by Bonifacio Abdon (1876-1944), Marcelo Adonay, Jose A. Estella, Cayetano Jacobe (b. 1876), Vicente Marifosqui, Juan Hernandez, Alejandro Francisco, Crispino Reyes, and Teresa Zapata.
list.text_description: The Asociacion Musical de Filipinas is formed by Bonifacio Abdon (1876-1944), Marcelo Adonay, Jose A. Estella, Cayetano Jacobe (b. 1876), Vicente Marifosqui, Juan Hernandez, Alejandro Francisco, Crispino Reyes, and Teresa Zapata.

list.media_caption: Sheet music cover of “Ang Maya,” 1905
list.article_title: Maria Carpena (1886-1915) records the Estella masterpiece “Ang Maya,” which becomes very successful.
list.text_description: Maria Carpena (1886-1915) records the Estella masterpiece “Ang Maya,” which becomes very successful.

list.media_caption: Philippine Constabulary Band performance, Manila, 1946
list.article_title: The PC Band returns to the USA to play in the inauguration of William Taft as president of the USA. The group also tours with sensational concerts in Boston, New York, Chicago, Washington, D.C. and San Francisco.
list.text_description: The PC Band returns to the USA to play in the inauguration of William Taft as president of the USA. The group also tours with sensational concerts in Boston, New York, Chicago, Washington, D.C. and San Francisco.

list.media_caption: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago
list.article_title: Bonifacio Abdon writes Misang Tagalog sa Balintawak, the first complete mass in Tagalog, at the request of the Aglipayan Church.
list.text_description: Bonifacio Abdon writes Misang Tagalog sa Balintawak, the first complete mass in Tagalog, at the request of the Aglipayan Church.

list.media_caption: Reformist writer Jose Rizal
list.article_title: The June issue of the Cultura Filipina lists 68 compositions between 1899 and 1910, which are dedicated to Jose Rizal or based on his works.
list.text_description: The June issue of the Cultura Filipina lists 68 compositions between 1899 and 1910, which are dedicated to Jose Rizal or based on his works.

list.media_caption: The Manila Symphony Orchestra, 2014
list.article_title: The Monday Musical Club, an organization of US Army officers and soldiers, organizes the Manila Symphony Orchestra (not to be confused with that founded by Alexander Lippay in 1922).
list.text_description: The Monday Musical Club, an organization of US Army officers and soldiers, organizes the Manila Symphony Orchestra (not to be confused with that founded by Alexander Lippay in 1922).

list.media_caption: Progressive Music Series, an anthology of Filipino folk songs, used as educational material during the American period
list.article_title: Norberto Romualdez (1875-1941), through Horatio Parker and Silver Burdett Company, compiles arranged Philippine music for The Philippine Progressive Series, which is used as a music textbook in public schools thereafter.
list.text_description: Norberto Romualdez (1875-1941), through Horatio Parker and Silver Burdett Company, compiles arranged Philippine music for The Philippine Progressive Series, which is used as a music textbook in public schools thereafter.

list.media_caption: UP Symphony Orchestra rehearsal conducted by Ramon Tapales, University of the Philippines, Quezon City, 1964
list.media_credit: UP College of Music Library Collection
list.article_title: After years of proposing bills in the Philippine Assembly, Senator Joaquin Luna (b. 1874) succeeds in getting passed into law (1915) the bill creating the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music, with support by first Filipino president of UP Ignacio Villamor (1863-1933) and with guitarist-scientist Fernando Canon (1860-1938) as secretary of the conservatory.
list.text_description: After years of proposing bills in the Philippine Assembly, Senator Joaquin Luna (b. 1874) succeeds in getting passed into law (1915) the bill creating the University of the Philippines (UP) Conservatory of Music, with support by first Filipino president of UP Ignacio Villamor (1863-1933) and with guitarist-scientist Fernando Canon (1860-1938) as secretary of the conservatory.

list.media_caption: Invitation for the sarsuwela Dalagang Bukid to be performed at the Teatro Zorrilla on Azcarraga,  now Claro M. Recto Avenue, in Manila, 1919
list.article_title: The sarsuwela Dalagang Bukid by Hermogenes Ilagan (1873–1943) is first staged, with music by Leon Ignacio (1882–1967). Because of its success, it is adapted into a silent film of the same title in 1919, becoming the first Philippine-produced film.
list.text_description: The sarsuwela Dalagang Bukid by Hermogenes Ilagan (1873–1943) is first staged, with music by Leon Ignacio (1882–1967). Because of its success, it is adapted into a silent film of the same title in 1919, becoming the first Philippine-produced film.

list.media_caption: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago
list.article_title: Francisco Santiago (1889-1947) composes “Anak ng Dalita,” which is considered the first art song kundiman, to be followed by Bonifacio Abdon’s “Kundiman” and Nicanor Abelardo’s “Kung Hindi Man” in 1920.
list.text_description: Francisco Santiago (1889-1947) composes “Anak ng Dalita,” which is considered the first art song kundiman, to be followed by Bonifacio Abdon’s “Kundiman” and Nicanor Abelardo’s “Kung Hindi Man” in 1920.

list.media_caption: Epifanio de los Santos, notable Filipino writer in Spanish
list.article_title: Epifanio de los Santos (1871–1928) publishes “Folk-Lore Musical de Filipinas” in El Debate.
list.text_description: Epifanio de los Santos (1871–1928) publishes “Folk-Lore Musical de Filipinas” in El Debate.

list.media_caption: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago
list.article_title: Francisco Santiago publishes arrangements of Filipino Folk Songs such as “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut) and “Leron-leron Sinta,” collected by Emilia S. Cavan.
list.text_description: Francisco Santiago publishes arrangements of Filipino Folk Songs such as “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut) and “Leron-leron Sinta,” collected by Emilia S. Cavan.

list.media_caption: Original string quartet of the Manila Chamber Music Society composed of, left to right,  Bonifacio Abdon, Francisco Avellana, Felipe Marin, and Jose Carrion
list.article_title: The Manila Chamber Music Society is founded, with Bonifacio Abdon as primary mover.
list.text_description: The Manila Chamber Music Society is founded, with Bonifacio Abdon as primary mover.

list.media_caption: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago
list.article_title: Francisco Santiago presents his Piano Concerto in B-flat minor as a requirement for his doctorate of music degree at the Chicago Musical College. Santiago is the first Filipino to hold a doctoral degree in music, major in music composition.
list.text_description: Francisco Santiago presents his Piano Concerto in B-flat minor as a requirement for his doctorate of music degree at the Chicago Musical College. Santiago is the first Filipino to hold a doctoral degree in music, major in music composition.

list.media_caption: KZIB broadcasting staff, 1938
list.media_credit: Photo courtesy of National Economic Protectionism Association
list.article_title: Isaac Beck’s radio station KZIB begins broadcast of Filipino songs rendered by Naty Arellano and other Columbia artists.
list.text_description: Isaac Beck’s radio station KZIB begins broadcast of Filipino songs rendered by Naty Arellano and other Columbia artists.

list.media_caption: The Manila Symphony Orchestra performing Lahing Kayumanggi, 2010
list.article_title: The Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) is founded by Alexander Lippay (1892-1939). One of the oldest existing symphonic orchestras in Asia, it introduces new concert programming, changing the way the urban audiences listen to conservatory music.
list.text_description: The Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) is founded by Alexander Lippay (1892-1939). One of the oldest existing symphonic orchestras in Asia, it introduces new concert programming, changing the way the urban audiences listen to conservatory music.

list.media_caption: Luva Adameit, middle, teacher of classical ballet to the first generation of Filipino dancers and choreographers, ca 1922
list.article_title: Luva Adameit (1895-1948), Polish dancer, arrives in Manila, where she creates stylized orientalist ballets on local themes such as “Planting Rice” and the folk dance “Cariñosa.” This pioneering stance would continue with Anita Kane’s ballet “Mariang Makiling” in 1939, with music by Ramon Tapales.
list.text_description: Luva Adameit (1895-1948), Polish dancer, arrives in Manila, where she creates stylized orientalist ballets on local themes such as “Planting Rice” and the folk dance “Cariñosa.” This pioneering stance would continue with Anita Kane’s ballet “Mariang Makiling” in 1939, with music by Ramon Tapales.

list.media_caption: Notable Filipino opera singers, from left, Jovita Fuentes, Isang Tapales, Dalisay Aldaba, and Conching Rosal
list.media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
list.article_title: Jovita Fuentes (1895-1978) records “Ay Kalisud” (Ah, Misery) and other Filipino folk songs for Odeon Records in Germany.
list.text_description: Jovita Fuentes (1895-1978) records “Ay Kalisud” (Ah, Misery) and other Filipino folk songs for Odeon Records in Germany.

list.media_caption: National Artists for music, Atang de la Rama, 1987
list.media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
list.article_title: Constancio de Guzman (1903-1982) composes the nationalist kundiman “Bayan Ko” (My Country) with lyrics by Jose Corazon de Jesus (1896-1932). De Guzman was a student of Abelardo in UP. Atang de la Rama (1905-1991) popularizes the song.
list.text_description: Constancio de Guzman (1903-1982) composes the nationalist kundiman “Bayan Ko” (My Country) with lyrics by Jose Corazon de Jesus (1896-1932). De Guzman was a student of Abelardo in UP. Atang de la Rama (1905-1991) popularizes the song.

list.media_caption: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago
list.article_title: Francisco Santiago wins two composition contests “Cristo Rey” and “Himno del Congreso Eucaristico.”
list.text_description: Francisco Santiago wins two composition contests “Cristo Rey” and “Himno del Congreso Eucaristico.”

list.media_caption: Sheet music cover of “Sa Kabukiran,” 1939
list.article_title: Manuel Velez (1894-1959) composes a balitaw romansada (composed balitaw) “Sa Kabukiran” in 1928.
list.text_description: Manuel Velez (1894-1959) composes a balitaw romansada (composed balitaw) “Sa Kabukiran” in 1928.

list.media_caption: Carlos P. Romulo, one of the announcers on  KZRC-Voice of Freedom
list.article_title: Radio Corporation of the Philippines opens radio station KZRC (now DYRC), the oldest radio station in Cebu, which later showcases the music of local composers Thomas Villaflor (b. 1900), Domingo Lopez (1912-1981), Ben Zubiri (1911-1969), and others.
list.text_description: Radio Corporation of the Philippines opens radio station KZRC (now DYRC), the oldest radio station in Cebu, which later showcases the music of local composers Thomas Villaflor (b. 1900), Domingo Lopez (1912-1981), Ben Zubiri (1911-1969), and others.

list.media_caption: Filipino art song composers, clockwise from top left,  Francisco Buencamino Sr, Bonifacio Abdon, Antonio Molina,  and Francisco Santiago
list.article_title: Francisco Santiago assumes his post as the first Filipino director of the UP Conservatory of Music.
list.text_description: Francisco Santiago assumes his post as the first Filipino director of the UP Conservatory of Music.

list.media_caption: Prewar Manila Metropolitan Theater facade
list.article_title: Metropolitan Theater in Plaza Lawton is inaugurated, with Jose Estella’s opera “Lakambini.” It will be the site of major music events until WWII when it is destroyed.
list.text_description: Metropolitan Theater in Plaza Lawton is inaugurated, with Jose Estella’s opera “Lakambini.” It will be the site of major music events until WWII when it is destroyed.

list.media_caption: National Artists for music, Antonio J. Molina, awarded in 1973
list.media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
list.article_title: Antonio Molina (1894-1980) pioneers a choral cycle using Filipino folk songs in his First Choral Cycle.
list.text_description: Antonio Molina (1894-1980) pioneers a choral cycle using Filipino folk songs in his First Choral Cycle.

list.media_caption: Scene from CCP’s La Traviata, 1992, set in late 19th century Manila
list.article_title: Victorino Carrion (voice teacher), Bonifacio Abdon (conductor), and Juan Javier (impresario) revive the opera by staging Aida (in February); La Traviata (May); Cavelleria Rusticana (August); and Lucia di Lammermoor (September).
list.text_description: Victorino Carrion (voice teacher), Bonifacio Abdon (conductor), and Juan Javier (impresario) revive the opera by staging Aida (in February); La Traviata (May); Cavelleria Rusticana (August); and Lucia di Lammermoor (September).

list.media_caption: Mila del Sol singing with the SSS Trio or Silos Sisters in  Giliw Ko, 1939, with music by Juan Silos Jr and Ariston Avelino
list.article_title: Sarsuwela films such as Bituing Marikit (1937), Nasaan Ka Irog (1937), Giliw Ko (1939), Pakiusap (1940), are made.
list.text_description: Sarsuwela films such as Bituing Marikit (1937), Nasaan Ka Irog (1937), Giliw Ko (1939), Pakiusap (1940), are made.

list.media_caption: Francisca Reyes-Tolentino (later Aquino), in striped skirt, learning a Kalinga dance, 1962; and, previous, Philippine National Dances, her anthology of indigenous and folk dances documented from all over the archipelago
list.article_title: Francisca Reyes-Tolentino (later Aquino) collaborates with Ramon Tolentino and Antonino Buenaventura in collecting folk dances.
list.text_description: Francisca Reyes-Tolentino (later Aquino) collaborates with Ramon Tolentino and Antonino Buenaventura in collecting folk dances.

list.media_caption: KZRM shortwave listening QSL card,  signed by managing director Carlos P. Romulo, ca 1930
list.media_credit: Photo courtesy of Amateur Radio Station
list.article_title: Juan Silos Jr (1898-1988) introduces the Silos Sisters in KZRM’s radio program Manila Radiolites in 1934-35.
list.text_description: Juan Silos Jr (1898-1988) introduces the Silos Sisters in KZRM’s radio program Manila Radiolites in 1934-35.

list.media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Ramon Tapales in 1992
list.media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
list.article_title: In 1935, Ramon Tapales (1906-1995) founds the Philippine Cultural Concert Society Symphony Orchestra, which exists until 1939.
list.text_description: In 1935, Ramon Tapales (1906-1995) founds the Philippine Cultural Concert Society Symphony Orchestra, which exists until 1939.

list.media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Mike Velarde, 1986
list.media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
list.article_title: Miguel Velarde (1913-1986) composes a love song in danza style “Dahil sa Iyo.”
list.text_description: Miguel Velarde (1913-1986) composes a love song in danza style “Dahil sa Iyo.”

list.media_caption: Bodabil rehearsal, with musicians at orchestra pit, ca 1950
list.article_title: Stage shows, the expanded bodabil, rises to popularity, showcasing musical, radio, and film artists, and directed by film directors.
list.text_description: Stage shows, the expanded bodabil, rises to popularity, showcasing musical, radio, and film artists, and directed by film directors.

list.media_caption: UST Symphony Orchestra performing at the 2015 Pasinaya Arts Festival, CCP, Manila
list.article_title: UST’s conservatory of music is founded with Manuel de Cuerva as its first director and Rev Gregorio Garcia OP as regent.
list.text_description: UST’s conservatory of music is founded with Manuel de Cuerva as its first director and Rev Gregorio Garcia OP as regent.

list.media_caption: Manila Cathedral Choir conducted by Fr John Van de Steen, CICM, 1966
list.article_title: Belgian priest John van de Steen, CICM arrives in Manila, organizing church choirs and directing their musical activities until his death in 1987.
list.text_description: Belgian priest John van de Steen, CICM arrives in Manila, organizing church choirs and directing their musical activities until his death in 1987.

list.media_caption: Priscilla, the “Kolynos” girl, with pianists Rafael Artigas, left, and Ariston Avelino
list.article_title: For Sampaguita musicals, Tirso Cruz composes for Isang Sulyap Mo, Tita (1953, starring Pancho Magalona and Tita Duran) and Constancio de Guzman, Maalaala Mo Kaya (1954, starring Carmen Rosales and Rogelio de la Rosa); for LVN, Juan Silos, Jr composes for Batangueña (1953) and Waray Waray (1954), both films starring Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa; for Premiere, Santiago Suarez composes for Bakya Mo Neneng (1947, starring Rosa del Rosario and Leopoldo Salcedo).
list.text_description: For Sampaguita musicals, Tirso Cruz composes for Isang Sulyap Mo, Tita (1953, starring Pancho Magalona and Tita Duran) and Constancio de Guzman, Maalaala Mo Kaya (1954, starring Carmen Rosales and Rogelio de la Rosa); for LVN, Juan Silos, Jr composes for Batangueña (1953) and Waray Waray (1954), both films starring Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa; for Premiere, Santiago Suarez composes for Bakya Mo Neneng (1947, starring Rosa del Rosario and Leopoldo Salcedo).

list.media_caption: National Artists for music, Antonino R. Buenaventura, 1988
list.media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
list.article_title: Antonino Buenaventura premieres Mindanao Sketches after his decade-long research on Manobo music in connection with a project on Folk Songs and Dances at the University of the Philippines (UP).
list.text_description: Antonino Buenaventura premieres Mindanao Sketches after his decade-long research on Manobo music in connection with a project on Folk Songs and Dances at the University of the Philippines (UP).

list.media_caption: Balitaw performed in Guadalupe, Cebu, 1990
list.article_title: DYRC radio station in Cebu promotes Cebuano balitaw with singer pair Antonio Bohol and Josefina Bacalso, following the fame of prewar pair Pedro Alfafara and Nicolasa Caniban.
list.text_description: DYRC radio station in Cebu promotes Cebuano balitaw with singer pair Antonio Bohol and Josefina Bacalso, following the fame of prewar pair Pedro Alfafara and Nicolasa Caniban.

list.media_caption: Popular radio performer Cecil Lloyd
list.article_title: Cecil Lloyd puts up one of the first known Filipino-owned recording companies, the Philippine Recording system (PRS).
list.text_description: Cecil Lloyd puts up one of the first known Filipino-owned recording companies, the Philippine Recording system (PRS).

list.media_caption: National Artists for music, Lucio D. San Pedro, 1991
list.media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
list.article_title: Lucio San Pedro composes his only concerto, Concerto for Violin and Orchestra, which utilizes the Igorot tune, “Naantoay,” in its final movement.
list.text_description: Lucio San Pedro composes his only concerto, Concerto for Violin and Orchestra, which utilizes the Igorot tune, “Naantoay,” in its final movement.

list.media_caption: National Artists for music, Levi Celerio, 1997
list.media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
list.article_title: Levi Celerio writes the lyrics for Lucio D. San Pedro’s composition “Sa Ugoy ng Duyan”.
list.text_description: Levi Celerio writes the lyrics for Lucio D. San Pedro’s composition “Sa Ugoy ng Duyan”.

list.media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Ramon Tapales, 1992
list.media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
list.article_title: Ramon Tapales (1906-1995) publishes the series Singing and Growing for Primary Grades, which discusses compositions and folk songs, with some sample songs from the United States and various European countries.
list.text_description: Ramon Tapales (1906-1995) publishes the series Singing and Growing for Primary Grades, which discusses compositions and folk songs, with some sample songs from the United States and various European countries.

list.media_caption: Artists singing patriotic songs during the 1986 EDSA Revolt
list.article_title: Mambo Magsaysay, Magsaysay’s campaign song fills the airwaves. It will be used as the station ID of Radyo Bandido during the February 1986 EDSA Revolt.
list.text_description: Mambo Magsaysay, Magsaysay’s campaign song fills the airwaves. It will be used as the station ID of Radyo Bandido during the February 1986 EDSA Revolt.

list.media_caption: Renowned Filipino composers, from left, Lucrecia Kasilag, Rodolfo Cornejo, Lucino Sacramento, Antonio Molina, Eliseo Pajaro,  Antonino Buenaventura, Felipe Padilla de Leon, and Lucio San Pedro, 1956
list.article_title: Corazon Maceda and Crispina Garcia publish Philippine Choruses for All Occasions, a compilation of choral arrangements of folk songs by Lucio San Pedro, Francisco Santiago, Francisco Buencamino, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Antonio Molina, and Corazon Maceda.
list.text_description: Corazon Maceda and Crispina Garcia publish Philippine Choruses for All Occasions, a compilation of choral arrangements of folk songs by Lucio San Pedro, Francisco Santiago, Francisco Buencamino, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Antonio Molina, and Corazon Maceda.

list.media_caption: National Artists for music, Felipe Padilla  de Leon, 1997
list.media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection, Philippine Daily Inquirer
list.article_title: To eliminate the practice called tambakan, unite local bands in the country, and promote good band music, the Pambansang Samahan ng Mga Banda sa Pilipinas (National Band Association of the Philippines) or PASAMBAP is organized by Felipe Padilla De Leon.
list.text_description: To eliminate the practice called tambakan, unite local bands in the country, and promote good band music, the Pambansang Samahan ng Mga Banda sa Pilipinas (National Band Association of the Philippines) or PASAMBAP is organized by Felipe Padilla De Leon.

list.media_caption: Jazz band with Lito Molina on the alto sax, left, Angel Peña on the upright bass, behind, and Emil Mijares at the piano, among others, ca 1965
list.article_title: Upsilon Sigma Phi Fraternity in UP begins its series of “experimental jazz,” which features jazz that appropriate folk songs such as Narding Aristorenas’s “Planting Rice” and Angel Peña’s “Bagbagtulambing.”
list.text_description: Upsilon Sigma Phi Fraternity in UP begins its series of “experimental jazz,” which features jazz that appropriate folk songs such as Narding Aristorenas’s “Planting Rice” and Angel Peña’s “Bagbagtulambing.”

list.media_caption: Former first lady Luz B. Magsaysay, second from right, with members of the Music Promotion Foundation  of the Philippines, left to right, Jose Lauchengco, Lucrecia Kasilag, and chair Jovita Fuentes, 1959
list.article_title: Under the Republic Act No. 1370, the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP) is created to function, among others, as a scholarship-granting agency for poor but talented students.
list.text_description: Under the Republic Act No. 1370, the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines (MPFP) is created to function, among others, as a scholarship-granting agency for poor but talented students.

list.media_caption: Members of the League of Filipino Composers, from left, Francisco Feliciano, Alfredo Buenaventura, Lucrecia Kasilag,  Ramon Santos, Antonino Buenaventura, Josefino Toledo, and Restituto Umali, ca 1980
list.article_title: The League of Filipino Composers is founded to stress the importance of creating a body of Filipino art music in the conservatory tradition.
list.text_description: The League of Filipino Composers is founded to stress the importance of creating a body of Filipino art music in the conservatory tradition.

list.media_caption: Scene from Carmen, 1956
list.article_title: Bizet’s opera Carmen is translated into Tagalog and staged successfully by the Manila Symphony Society in the FEU Auditorium in 1956.
list.text_description: Bizet’s opera Carmen is translated into Tagalog and staged successfully by the Manila Symphony Society in the FEU Auditorium in 1956.

list.media_caption: Gawad CCP Para sa Sining (Musika) awardees, Nena del Rosario, 1997
list.media_credit: CCP Collection, Filipinas Heritage Library,  Fanny Aldaba-Lim, Pablo Tariman, Ryan Cayabyab
list.article_title: Nena del Rosario, piano prodigy, earns an artist diploma in Curtis Institute.
list.text_description: Nena del Rosario, piano prodigy, earns an artist diploma in Curtis Institute.

list.media_caption: A collection of Visayan folk songs, published by Silliman Music Foundation Inc in 1957
list.article_title: Priscilla Magdamo publishes the multi-volume Philippine Folk Songs: Songs of the Visayas, through the Silliman Music Foundation, Inc., after her field work in Banga, Aklan in 1956.
list.text_description: Priscilla Magdamo publishes the multi-volume Philippine Folk Songs: Songs of the Visayas, through the Silliman Music Foundation, Inc., after her field work in Banga, Aklan in 1956.

list.media_caption: Scene from Noli Me Tangere, 1987
list.article_title: Felipe Padilla de Leon’s opera Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), with libretto by Guillermo Tolentino (1890 – 1976), is staged.
list.text_description: Felipe Padilla de Leon’s opera Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), with libretto by Guillermo Tolentino (1890 – 1976), is staged.

list.media_caption: National Artists for music, Antonino R. Buenaventura, 1988
list.media_credit: CCP Collection, National Library of the Philippines Collection
list.article_title: Antonino Buenaventura receives the Republic Cultural Heritage award.
list.text_description: Antonino Buenaventura receives the Republic Cultural Heritage award.

list.media_caption: Dr Ramon P. Santos conducting an orchestra and choir at the Nicanor Abelardo Hall Auditorium of  the University of the Philippines in Diliman, Quezon City

Freddie Aguilar’s “Anak” (Child) will sell at an unprecedented 30,000 copies and will be translated into several foreign languages, making it the most successful music industry product in Philippine history.

list.media_caption: Dinagyang Festival, Iloilo City, 2017
list.article_title: Local Government of Cebu secularizes the devotional dance sinulog by initiating street dancing as part of the feast of Santo Niño. Parallel initiatives in the secularization of sacred expressions, now linked to tourism, is manifest in Aklan’s Ati-Atihan and Ilo-ilo’s Dinagyang. Secular street dancing is demonstrated in Davao’s Kadayawan festival and Baguio City Panagbenga Festival.

list.article_title: Musical Theater Philippines stages Larawan based on Nick Joaquin’s play A Portrait of the Artist as Filipino, with lyrics by Rolando Tinio and music by Ryan Cayabyab. It is made into a movie in 2017.

list.article_title: Four new sarsuwela win the National Sarsuwela Competition: Mario O’Hara’s “Palasyo ni Valentin,” with music by Minda Azarcon; George de Jesus III’s “Paglayang Minamahal,” with music by Jeffrey Hernandez; Bienvenido Lumbera’s “Hibik ng Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw,” with music by Lucien Letaba; and Melba Camagay’s “Bayan, Isang Paa na Lamang,” with music by Lucio San Pedro.

list.media_caption: Book cover of Gongs & Bamboo, 1998

list.media_caption: San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra performing under conductor Ryan Cayabyab
list.article_title: Under the artistic direction of Ryan Cayabyab, the San Miguel Foundation for the Performing Arts founds the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra and San Miguel Master Chorale in 2001. It exists until 2007, producing notable records of Filipino music.

list.media_caption: Sarah Geronimo performing in Cebu City, 2013
list.article_title: TV singing contests are revived with Search for a Star, 2003; Star in a Million, ABS-CBN 2003; Little Big Star, ABS-CBN, 2005-2007; Philippine Idol, TV5 and GMA Network, 2006-2008; Pinoy Idol, GMA Network, 2006; Pinoy Pop Superstar, GMA, 2006; and The Voice of the Philippines, ABS-CBN2013. Sarah Geronimo, Rachel Ann Go, and Christian Bautista are some of the winners in these contests.

list.media_caption: FilHarmonika with conductor, Gerard Salonga, performing at the Insular Life Theater, Alabang, 2008
list.article_title: Global Studio Orchestra (GC4) or FILharmoniKa with conductor Gerard Salonga fulfills outsourcing needs of commercial recording and film scoring needs of the global market. Salonga will later move on to lead the ABS-CBN Philharmonic Orchestra, also for the same goals.

list.media_caption: Internet discovery Charice Pempengco on the cover of her self-titled EP, 2008
list.article_title: Charice Pempengco guests at the Ellen DeGeneres Show after the host sees her performances on YouTube. This is followed by invitations from Oprah Winfrey and a contract from the music producer David Foster.
